column2: THE BIRD OF PREY BROUGHT DOWN

column2: Cold on the shore, in the raw cold of that leaden crisis in the four-and-twenty hours when the vital force of all the noblest and prettiest things that live is at its lowest, the three watchers looked each at the blank faces of the other two, and all at the blank face of Riderhood in his boat.
column3: Cold on the shore, in the raw cold of that leaden crisis in the four and twenty hours when the vital force of all the noblest and prettiest things that live is at its lowest, the three watchers looked each at the blank faces of the other two, and all at the blank face of Riderhood in his boat.

column2: 'Gaffer's boat, Gaffer in luck again, and yet no Gaffer!' So spake Riderhood, staring disconsolate.
column3: 'Gaffer's boat, Gaffer in luck again, and yet no Gaffer!' So spake Riderhood, staring disconsolate.

column2: As if with one accord, they all turned their eyes towards the light of the fire shining through the window.
column3: As if with one accord, they all turned their eyes towards the light of the fire shining through the window.

column2: It was fainter and duller.
column3: It was fainter and duller.

column2: Perhaps fire, like the higher animal and vegetable life it helps to sustain, has its greatest tendency towards death, when the night is dying and the day is not yet born.
column3: Perhaps fire, like the higher animal and vegetable life it helps to sustain, has its greatest tendency towards death, when the night is dying and the day is not yet born.

column2: Come aboard of mine, and see for your own-selves.'

column2: There was a little backwardness in complying, for the freight looked too much for the boat; but on Riderhood's protesting 'that he had had half a dozen, dead and alive, in her afore now, and she was nothing deep in the water nor down in the stern even then, to speak of;' they carefully took their places, and trimmed the crazy thing.

column2: Steady!' cried Eugene (he had recovered immediately on embarking), as they bumped heavily against a pile; and then in a lower voice reversed his late apostrophe by remarking ('I wish the boat of my honourable and gallant friend may be endowed with philanthropy enough not to turn bottom-upward and extinguish us!) Steady, steady!

column2: Indeed he had the full benefit of it, and it so mauled him, though he bent his head low and tried to present nothing but the mangy cap to it, that he dropped under the lee of a tier of shipping, and they lay there until it was over.

column2: The squall had come up, like a spiteful messenger before the morning; there followed in its wake a ragged tear of light which ripped the dark clouds until they showed a great grey hole of day.

column2: They were all shivering, and everything about them seemed to be shivering; the river itself; craft, rigging, sails, such early smoke as there yet was on the shore.
column3: They were all shivering, and everything about them seemed to be shivering; the river itself; craft, rigging, sails, such early smoke as there yet was on the shore.

column2: Black with wet, and altered to the eye by white patches of hail and sleet, the huddled buildings looked lower than usual, as if they were cowering, and had shrunk with the cold.
column3: Black with wet, and altered to the eye by white patches of hail and sleet, the huddled buildings looked lower than usual, as if they were cowering, and had shrunk with the cold.

column2: Very little life was to be seen on either bank, windows and doors were shut, and the staring black and white letters upon wharves and warehouses 'looked,' said Eugene to Mortimer, 'like inscriptions over the graves of dead businesses.'
column3: Very little life was to be seen on either bank, windows and doors were shut, and the staring black and white letters upon wharves and warehouses 'looked,' said Eugene to Mortimer, 'like inscriptions over the graves of dead businesses.'

column2: As they glided slowly on, keeping under the shore and sneaking in and out among the shipping by back-alleys of water, in a pilfering way that seemed to be their boatman's normal manner of progression, all the objects among which they crept were so huge in contrast with their wretched boat, as to threaten to crush it.
column3: As they glided slowly on, keeping under the shore and sneaking in and out among the shipping by back alleys of water, in a pilfering way that seemed to be their boatman's normal manner of progression, all the objects among which they crept were so huge in contrast with their wretched boat, as to threaten to crush it.

column2: Not a ship's hull, with its rusty iron links of cable run out of hawse-holes long discoloured with the iron's rusty tears, but seemed to be there with a fell intention. Not a figure-head but had the menacing look of bursting forward to run them down.
column3: Not a ship's hull, with its rusty iron links of cable run out of hawse holes long discoloured with the iron's rusty tears, but seemed to be there with a fell intention. Not a figure head but had the menacing look of bursting forward to run them down.

column2: Not a sluice gate, or a painted scale upon a post or wall, showing the depth of water, but seemed to hint, like the dreadfully facetious Wolf in bed in Grandmamma's cottage, 'That's to drown YOU in, my dears!' Not a lumbering black barge, with its cracked and blistered side impending over them, but seemed to suck at the river with a thirst for sucking them under.
column3: Not a sluice gate, or a painted scale upon a post or wall, showing the depth of water, but seemed to hint, like the dreadfully facetious Wolf in bed in Grandmamma's cottage, 'That's to drown YOU in, my dears!' Not a lumbering black barge, with its cracked and blistered side impending over them, but seemed to suck at the river with a thirst for sucking them under.

column2: And everything so vaunted the spoiling influences of water--discoloured copper, rotten wood, honey-combed stone, green dank deposit--that the after-consequences of being crushed, sucked under, and drawn down, looked as ugly to the imagination as the main event.
column3: And everything so vaunted the spoiling influences of water-discoloured copper, rotten wood, honey combed stone, green dank deposit-that the after consequences of being crushed, sucked under, and drawn down, looked as ugly to the imagination as the main event.

column2: Some half-hour of this work, and Riderhood unshipped his sculls, stood holding on to a barge, and hand over hand long-wise along the barge's side gradually worked his boat under her head into a secret little nook of scummy water.
column3: Some half hour of this work, and Riderhood unshipped his sculls, stood holding on to a barge, and hand over hand long wise along the barge's side gradually worked his boat under her head into a secret little nook of scummy water.

column2: And driven into that nook, and wedged as he had described, was Gaffer's boat; that boat with the stain still in it, bearing some resemblance to a muffled human form.
column3: And driven into that nook, and wedged as he had described, was Gaffer's boat; that boat with the stain still in it, bearing some resemblance to a muffled human form.

column2: You MUST come up. I mean to have you.'

column2: Words never to be answered, those, upon the earth-side of the grave.

column2: The wind sweeps jeeringly over Father, whips him with the frayed ends of his dress and his jagged hair, tries to turn him where he lies stark on his back, and force his face towards the rising sun, that he may be shamed the more.

column2: Was it you, the voiceless and the dead?

column2: Soaking into this filthy ground as you lie here, is your own shape.

column2: Speak to us, the winds, the only listeners left you!

column3: But no Eugene was in all the view.

column2: Mr Inspector speedily returning down the wooden stairs, with a police constable, Lightwood asked him if he had seen his friend leave them?
column3: Mr Inspector speedily returning down the wooden stairs, with a police constable, Lightwood asked him if he had seen his friend leave them?

column2: Mr Inspector could not exactly say that he had seen him go, but had noticed that he was restless.
column3: Mr Inspector could not exactly say that he had seen him go, but had noticed that he was restless.

column2: 'Singular and entertaining combination, sir, your friend.'
column3: 'Singular and entertaining combination, sir, your friend.'

column2: 'I wish it had not been a part of his singular entertaining combination to give me the slip under these dreary circumstances at this time of the morning,' said Lightwood. 'Can we get anything hot to drink?'
column3: 'I wish it had not been a part of his singular entertaining combination to give me the slip under these dreary circumstances at this time of the morning,' said Lightwood. 'Can we get anything hot to drink?'

column2: We could, and we did.
column3: We could, and we did.

column2: In a public-house kitchen with a large fire.
column3: In a public house kitchen with a large fire.

column2: We got hot brandy and water, and it revived us wonderfully.
column3: We got hot brandy and water, and it revived us wonderfully.

column2: Mr Inspector having to Mr Riderhood announced his official intention of 'keeping his eye upon him', stood him in a corner of the fireplace, like a wet umbrella, and took no further outward and visible notice of that honest man, except ordering a separate service of brandy and water for him: apparently out of the public funds.
column3: Mr Inspector having to Mr Riderhood announced his official intention of 'keeping his eye upon him', stood him in a corner of the fireplace, like a wet umbrella, and took no further outward and visible notice of that honest man, except ordering a separate service of brandy and water for him: apparently out of the public funds.

column2: As Mortimer Lightwood sat before the blazing fire, conscious of drinking brandy and water then and there in his sleep, and yet at one and the same time drinking burnt sherry at the Six Jolly Fellowships, and lying under the boat on the river shore, and sitting in the boat that Riderhood rowed, and listening to the lecture recently concluded, and having to dine in the Temple with an unknown man, who described himself as M. H. F. Eugene Gaffer Harmon, and said he lived at Hailstorm,--as he passed through these curious vicissitudes of fatigue and slumber, arranged upon the scale of a dozen hours to the second, he became aware of answering aloud a communication of pressing importance that had never been made to him, and then turned it into a cough on beholding Mr Inspector.
column3: As Mortimer Lightwood sat before the blazing fire, conscious of drinking brandy and water then and there in his sleep, and yet at one and the same time drinking burnt sherry at the Six Jolly Fellowships, and lying under the boat on the river shore, and sitting in the boat that Riderhood rowed, and listening to the lecture recently concluded, and having to dine in the Temple with an unknown man, who described himself as m h f Eugene Gaffer Harmon, and said he lived at Hailstorm,--as he passed through these curious vicissitudes of fatigue and slumber, arranged upon the scale of a dozen hours to the second, he became aware of answering aloud a communication of pressing importance that had never been made to him, and then turned it into a cough on beholding Mr Inspector.

column2: For, he felt, with some natural indignation, that that functionary might otherwise suspect him of having closed his eyes, or wandered in his attention.
column3: For, he felt, with some natural indignation, that that functionary might otherwise suspect him of having closed his eyes, or wandered in his attention.

column2: 'Here just before us, you see,' said Mr Inspector.
column3: 'Here just before us, you see,' said Mr Inspector.

column2: 'I see,' said Lightwood, with dignity.
column3: 'I see,' said Lightwood, with dignity.

column2: 'And had hot brandy and water too, you see,' said Mr Inspector, 'and then cut off at a great rate.'
column3: 'And had hot brandy and water too, you see,' said Mr Inspector, 'and then cut off at a great rate.'

column2: 'Who?' said Lightwood.
column3: 'Who?' said Lightwood.

column2: 'Your friend, you know.'
column3: 'Your friend, you know.'

column2: 'I know,' he replied, again with dignity.
column3: 'I know,' he replied, again with dignity.

column2: After hearing, in a mist through which Mr Inspector loomed vague and large, that the officer took upon himself to prepare the dead man's daughter for what had befallen in the night, and generally that he took everything upon himself, Mortimer Lightwood stumbled in his sleep to a cab-stand, called a cab, and had entered the army and committed a capital military offence and been tried by court martial and found guilty and had arranged his affairs and been marched out to be shot, before the door banged.
column3: After hearing, in a mist through which Mr Inspector loomed vague and large, that the officer took upon himself to prepare the dead man's daughter for what had befallen in the night, and generally that he took everything upon himself, Mortimer Lightwood stumbled in his sleep to a cab stand, called a cab, and had entered the army and committed a capital military offence and been tried by court martial and found guilty and had arranged his affairs and been marched out to be shot, before the door banged.

column2: Hard work rowing the cab through the City to the Temple, for a cup of from five to ten thousand pounds value, given by Mr Boffin; and hard work holding forth at that immeasurable length to Eugene (when he had been rescued with a rope from the running pavement) for making off in that extraordinary manner!
column3: Hard work rowing the cab through the City to the Temple, for a cup of from five to ten thousand pounds value, given by Mr Boffin; and hard work holding forth at that immeasurable length to Eugene (when he had been rescued with a rope from the running pavement) for making off in that extraordinary manner!

column2: But he offered such ample apologies, and was so very penitent, that when Lightwood got out of the cab, he gave the driver a particular charge to be careful of him.
column3: But he offered such ample apologies, and was so very penitent, that when Lightwood got out of the cab, he gave the driver a particular charge to be careful of him.

column2: Which the driver (knowing there was no other fare left inside) stared at prodigiously.
column3: Which the driver (knowing there was no other fare left inside) stared at prodigiously.

column2: In short, the night's work had so exhausted and worn out this actor in it, that he had become a mere somnambulist.
column3: In short, the night's work had so exhausted and worn out this actor in it, that he had become a mere somnambulist.

column2: He was too tired to rest in his sleep, until he was even tired out of being too tired, and dropped into oblivion.
column3: He was too tired to rest in his sleep, until he was even tired out of being too tired, and dropped into oblivion.

column2: Late in the afternoon he awoke, and in some anxiety sent round to Eugene's lodging hard by, to inquire if he were up yet?
column3: Late in the afternoon he awoke, and in some anxiety sent round to Eugene's lodging hard by, to inquire if he were up yet?

column2: Oh yes, he was up.
column3: Oh yes, he was up.

column2: In fact, he had not been to bed.
column3: In fact, he had not been to bed.

column2: He had just come home.
column3: He had just come home.

column2: And here he was, close following on the heels of the message.
column3: And here he was, close following on the heels of the message.

column2: 'Why what bloodshot, draggled, dishevelled spectacle is this!' cried Mortimer.
column3: 'Why what bloodshot, draggled, dishevelled spectacle is this!' cried Mortimer.

column2: 'Are my feathers so very much rumpled?' said Eugene, coolly going up to the looking-glass.
column3: 'Are my feathers so very much rumpled?' said Eugene, coolly going up to the looking glass.

column2: They ARE rather out of sorts.
column3: They ARE rather out of sorts.

column2: But consider.
column3: But consider.

column2: Such a night for plumage!'
column3: Such a night for plumage!'

column2: 'Such a night?' repeated Mortimer.
column3: 'Such a night?' repeated Mortimer.

column2: 'What became of you in the morning?'
column3: 'What became of you in the morning?'

column2: 'My dear fellow,' said Eugene, sitting on his bed, 'I felt that we had bored one another so long, that an unbroken continuance of those relations must inevitably terminate in our flying to opposite points of the earth.
column3: 'My dear fellow,' said Eugene, sitting on his bed, 'I felt that we had bored one another so long, that an unbroken continuance of those relations must inevitably terminate in our flying to opposite points of the earth.

column2: I also felt that I had committed every crime in the Newgate Calendar.
column3: I also felt that I had committed every crime in the Newgate Calendar.

column2: So, for mingled considerations of friendship and felony, I took a walk.'
column3: So, for mingled considerations of friendship and felony, I took a walk.'
